Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Knowledge Networks and Development Information Translation across Scales

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research seeks to understand how people respond to environmental change and why they respond as they do. The challenge of translating ideas from one context to another is at the heart of any development intervention. Understanding how knowledge moves between different cultural contexts and levels of governance, and how it is mobilized to influence particular choices and outcomes, is crucial to devising and implementing effective solutions to socio-environmental problems. Researchers are becoming increasingly aware that knowledge, decision-making, and action are influenced by relations beyond just those between individual human actors. Meteorological events, environmental characteristics, technologies and infrastructures, graphic representations, and other factors also affect how knowledge is shared, interpreted, and applied. This complicated nexus of relationships, which acts at multiple and interacting scales from local and regional to national and international, makes it difficult to predict the effects of particular interventions, a challenging problem for both policy makers and for local people who are trying to cope with a changing world. The research funded by this award will investigate whether general predictive principles can be discerned by looking more closely at the interaction of these factors and scales in the context of a specific environmental adaptation project.

The research will be conducted by University of Georgia doctoral student, Jacob Weger, under the supervision of Dr. J. Peter Brosius. Weger will focus data collection on areas included in the Mekong Delta Plan, a Dutch-Vietnamese initiative outlining a 100-year plan for sustainable development. Few regions of the world are as threatened by climate change as the Mekong Delta where rising sea levels already are transforming the area into a predominantly brackish environment. Looking at how a comprehensive plan actually works in this challenging environment provides a unique research opportunity. Weger will conduct ethnographic research at sites spanning multiple levels of governance: the Netherlands, Vietnam, and a coastal province of the Mekong Delta. He will collect data using a suite of methods: in-depth interviews, document analysis, participant observation of meetings, workshops, and farming practices, and social network analysis. These data will be used to construct generalized models of the networks linking levels of governance, as well as those that influence farmer decisions.The goal is to understand how knowledge moves and is interpreted across these levels as it influences local decision-making. Findings from this research will contribute to understanding how knowledge networks, translation politics, and other material conditions and constraints shape response to development interventions. Results will be shared with participants at all levels, including local communities, so that they, too, may contribute effectively to development planning and policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to investigate how the flow of information across scales of governance shapes efforts to adapt to climate change. The Mekong Delta, a crucial area of agricultural production for Vietnam, is also highly vulnerable to climate change, particularly the effects of sea level rise. Because of this, both domestic and international organizations are trying to steer the region’s development along a climate-resilient path, but how this unfolds will depend largely on local land-use decisions by farmers. One of the main initiatives behind this is the Mekong Delta Plan, a document produced by Dutch delta experts in partnership with the Vietnamese government in 2013. To successfully implement such a plan, knowledge and information must be shared across scales from the international to the local. Yet knowledge is never just transferred directly but rather is “translated” from one context to the next, reinterpreted to suit particular circumstances and interests. In order to understand how this works in practice, the researchers ask, “How is knowledge translated across multi-level governance networks to influence local livelihood decisions in transnational climate change adaptation initiatives?” 

The NSF-funded portion of the research took place over 12 months at multiple sites in Vietnam, with local-level focus on a coastal province of the Mekong Delta, Tra Vinh. The co-PI collected multiple sources of data, including from observations of meetings with government and development professionals; in-depth interviews with planners and policymakers, scientific experts, development professionals, agricultural extension workers, local officials, and farmers; information about farmer livelihoods, knowledge, and decision-making; data on the social networks and flows of information connecting these groups; and archival and policy documents concerning the evolution of land-use and infrastructure until today. The data is currently being analyzed for trends and emergent themes to help answer the question above. 

Adapting to the impacts of climate change is an immense challenge that all countries currently face. Successful adaptation requires effective communication and coordination across levels of governance, including among experts, policymakers, implementers, and local stakeholders. However, there is often a gap between initiatives promoted at wider scales and the needs, priorities, and understandings of local people faced with specific challenges, leading to ineffective and unsuccessful results. This research contributes to anthropological and social science knowledge about the movement of information across scales of governance, and the role of knowledge itself in shaping the trajectory of adaptation strategies. Results of the project will aid governance efforts in planning and implementing more effective and equitable responses to climate change everywhere.
